segments.text: This is side four.
This is side four.
This is side four.
Continuing the discussion of crossroads.

They plan to measure the immediate and long-range effects of the burst upon fish population of Bikini Atoll and the rate of repopulation through reproduction and immigration of the fish populations destroyed.

Since early planning indicated that the ecological phase of the future study of Bikini Atoll and surrounding waters was an important one, the primary responsibility for the biological survey rested with the U.S. National Museum.

The plans for the biological survey call for a quantitative inventory of flora and fauna at Bikini at any weak dock which would feel only moderate effects and at Rongerik not likely to be affected at all.
These inventories were to be made prior to the burst as soon afterwards as possible and at varying intervals for a considerable period to estimate long period effects and the rate of repopulation.
Three geologists from the geological survey were specifically selected.

to study bottom sediments using both bottom sampling and photographic methods, and to investigate the physiography and geology of the islands of the Bikini Atoll, the shore and beach processes, and the ecology of the coral reefs.

The purpose of the geological investigation was to study possible effects of the explosion, like erosion of the interface of Bikini Island by waves and currents, changes in bottom topography by transportation of sediment near the explosion, and radioactive effects on the bottom sediments in the coral reef.
On 11 March, the Bautist expedition composed of these advanced study activities began their scientific work in Bikini Lagoon.

In the latter part of December, wave measurements were among the topics of discussion in a conference called by the Bureau of Ordnance, which was attended by Rail Admiral, then Commodore Parsons, Rail Admiral Sahlberg, and representatives of the Bureau of Ships of the Manhattan District and the Los Alamos Laboratories.

The Alamos representatives particularly emphasized the importance of wave measurements and called upon Commander Revell to describe the proposed methods of measurement, which included portable echo sounders and bottom-mounted echo sounders.
Other work was done under the following people.

Suggestions for wave measurement were received from Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, the Admiralty Research Laboratory in England, the University of California Division of War Research, and the U.S. Navy Electronics Laboratory.
Suggestions from Mr. M.P.
O'Brien, Dean of the University of California Department of Engineering, for full
for model studies of wave generation, preliminary to the full-scale atomic studies, was subsequently carried out by his personnel and others.
On page 383, photogrammetry and television, we've mentioned some of this.
The head of the oceanography group recommended photogrammetry for wave measurements by means of simultaneous aerial and ground photography controlled by radio links.
for the installation of camera towers on the Atoll Islands, as well as television observations.
A special section of the group was organized for installing and operating two television transmitters on Bikini, two television receivers, and so forth.
The group also arranged that a series of model tests be undertaken under the direction of Professor J. W. Johnson of Dean O'Brien's staff.

The investigation was instituted at Woods Hole Laboratories, transferred to the Navy Taylor Model Base and finally to the Naval Warfare Mine Test Station, Solomons, as the size of the charges used in the investigation increased from one tenth of a pound to a thousand pounds.
On page 396, it's worthwhile reading the conclusions as stated as follows.
It seems that throughout the ages, each new weapon has been heralded as ringing the death knell of navies.
Undoubtedly, this vicious cycle commenced with the introduction of cannons on galleys, which immediately outmoded the ore-propelled ram and thereby ended the reign of Sea Power.
Whitehead's automotive torpedo assuredly placed the naval vessel in the proverbial mothballs.
Sea Power then came to its end when Mr. Holland perfected the submarine, and again with the advent of the airplanes.
but now it appears sea power which somehow not only managed to survive these other indefensible weapons but also managed to increase its influence is doomed once more.
This time it is the atomic bomb that sends the navies to their inglorious grave.

The student of history confesses that each new development, improvement, or invention has not diminished the naval vessel, but rather has expanded its importance, if not by utilization of that new invention to its own advantage, then by the development of defensive equipment or weapons which increased its power.
Let us say, in general conclusion,

that Operation Crossroads indicated that the destructive effect of the atomic bomb is 20,000 times greater than any other missile yet developed, which makes selectivity of targets impossible since non-military items will be destroyed just as surely as are the military objectives, that it can sink the largest ship afloat, and that the atomic bomb is a fact.
This conclusion, however,
has merely pointed the way for naval architects and strategists and tacticians.
As the advent of air power only aided in making sea power stronger, so may this new weapon of warfare merely make naval force more effective.
In page 396.
On page 473, chapter 25 of this book, what is past is prologue.
There's a summary that is worth reading into the record here.
To study the future, one must first look to the past.
This history then is a prologue of the Bureau of Ships, a record of wartime accomplishments almost unequal in scope, integration, and success of mission.

According to the extensive data presented in the preceding chapters, the Bureau's functions in attaining these accomplishments during the fiery months from 7 December 1941 to 14 August 1945 fell into the categories of planning, production, and maintenance, which may well be recapitulated briefly to describe the background from which the future will emanate.
One element of planning involved the efficacious allocation of over 20 billions of dollars during the war period.

This sum went into the purchase of 12 million tons of steel, an intake conservation of critical materials program which saved 30 million pounds of nickel, 20 million pounds of rubber, 9 million pounds of tin, 207 million pounds of copper, and resulted in a considerable financial economy.
It went into wages for some one million shipyard workers at the program's peak load, with over two million industrial workers being engaged in satellite industries at this same moment.
Two million dollars were used to expand shipyards,

and industrial plants to accommodate this comprehensive shipbuilding program involving over 40,000 contractors, and sizable appropriations were made to the Bureau of Ships' extensive training program, which involved 2,000 military and 4,000 civilian personnel, and to the elaborate design program involving 161 different types of vessels.
Production was concerned with the construction of 1,141 combatant vessels, 75,113 landing craft, 519 auxiliaries, which together with other types totaled 98,131 vessels of 7,465,046 tonnage.
produced during the war years.
In addition, 1,504 ships totaling over four and one half million tons were converted, while almost 1,200 ships of one third million tonnage were acquired.
Peak production for one month was reached in May 1944, when 4,475 vessels and craft were constructed and 30 million diesel horsepower were installed.
Compare this with the Navy on 7 December 1941, which included only 4,000 ships with 16 million steam and diesel horsepower.
It is of interest to compare the following figures showing the building periods required for specific types of vessels.
According to the maximum period, the average period, and the estimated average Japanese period, a conservative estimate must be accepted with reservation.
Battleships maximum 46, average 36, Japanese 48.
Destroyers maximum 30, average 12, Japanese 24.
Submarines 27,
average 11, Japanese 12.
LST, maximum nine, average three.
These must be months.
Electronics production proved almost as spectacular with the manufacture of 35,617 radar, radio, and sound equipment during the war years, plus 10,225 units for the Marine Corps.
Maintenance involved the production of varying quantities of over 2,500,000 individual service parts requiring 227 acres of warehousing.
Although repair and overhaul estimates are impossible to bring under a common denominator, it may be roughly estimated that over 20,000 ships were serviced each year.
Over 500 calls for salvage were answered, resulting in the saving of $700 million worth of shipping.
Finally, the vital and important post-war program includes $20 million appropriate for the preservation of the reserve fleet.

The principal objective and motivation for this study, however, is not to eulogize the accomplishment of the personnel of the Bureau, rather it is to gather up a summary of past experience from which data may be drawn as a basis in the formulation of future plans.
It makes several general considerations, which I need not go into here, but are worth reading, and the book itself is far from negligible, and I will repeat its title.
An administrative history of the Bureau of Ships during World War II, Volume 4.
First draft narrative prepared by the historical section of the Bureau of Ships.
End of this book report for the study at the first of this tape.
Stop.
After 1946,
I went to Scripps Institution of Oceanography on a GI barrel and joined first class of physical oceanography graduate students.
And I obtained a master's degree in 1948 along with such persons as Bob Reed, John Cochran, Don Pritchard, Harry Carter, Dale Leper,
in that group, most of whom went on to get their doctorate degrees.
I went to the Hydrographic Office and got a job under Richard Fleming, R. H. Fleming, now retired as Department Head of Oceanography at the University of Seattle.
Under him were a remarkable group of people.
When I got there, John Lyman,
now retired in Raleigh, North Carolina, was the assistant head of the section.
Under him were Tommy Austin, Louie Allen, Charlie Bates, Jim Hughes, Boyd Olsen, A.R.
Gordon, who graduated with me at Scripps, and others like Ben Richman, Max McLean, Leighton Kohler, and many others.
It is rather remarkable that so far as I know, Louie Allen, who passed away this past summer, is the first of this group to die.
He was the well-known and beloved weather reporter for the station, I believe it was the CBS station, in Washington, D.C.
but to his credit must be given the first attempt for ship routing using oceanographic and wave forecasts, a service which was later taken over by the Hydrographic Office itself.
In the two to three years that I was with the Hydrographic Office, the outstanding accomplishment from my point of view was the establishment
of the first converted Navy ships for oceanographic research, the San Pablo and another APA converted aircraft carrier, seaplane tender, a converted seaplane tender.
It was our job to outfit these vessels which Tommy Austin then initiated
as director of that group the first cruises which carried on and later were corroborated with the large multi-ship operations.

These were among the first ships to be taken out of mothballs and put back into service after World War II for ships of any size, and it was a major effort between the Hydrographic Office and the Bureau of Ships.

I felt much more at home at the Bureau of Ships, the Naval Oceanographic Office, and transferred over about 1951 and was immediately put in charge of taking care of the funding for the contracts for Woods Hole and Scripps Institution of Oceanography, working under Meredith D. Williams, Dick Williams.
and Ned Shearer, who were in that department, later succeeded by E. Vernon Potter, PhD, as the oceanographic and scientific group in the sonar design section of Old Butte Ships.
There were several important milestones to be considered between 1952 and 1969, which I consider to be the peak
of the oceanographic effort in the Navy.

The first was initiated by Gordon G. Lill, then head of the funding section at the Office of Naval Research, later succeeded by Arthur Maxwell, in which he, together with Arthur Maxwell and Phelan Jennings and Dick Vetter in that section, initiated
the Informal Coordinating Conference of Oceanography, CCO.
It soon became evident that we would have to broaden the base between BUSHPS and ONR, and the next people invited was Lionel K. Walford of the Bureau of Fisheries of the Department of Interior.
This Informal Coordinating Committee of Oceanography grew finally to have some 19 activities under its scope.
I think you will find it in Wink's book called The Politics of the Ocean, how this informal committee became important enough to get official recognition

and the Interagency Committee on Oceanography was established, which became quite powerful up to the time when Wink became the secretary for the committee and commission directed by Hubert Humphrey in the latter days.

Gordon Lill also developed the informal social group known as the American Miscellaneous Society, AMSOC, which originally was purely for social purposes but was later taken over as the activity that bid and helped design the Project Moho.
I believe Gordon Lill had left and gone commercial for a while with the Submarine Signal Company, and Arthur Maxwell,
was head of the department at ONR, where Phelan Jennings and Dick Vetter and he and others decided there should be a 10-year oceanographic plan.
Eventually, there were two such plans succeeding each other.
Due credit for the fact that the plan got off the ground at all should be given to Gilbert Maton, then with J.I.
Thompson Company,

who with his skill took the various opinions of King Cooper, Dick Better, Phelan Jennings and others and made a comprehensive report as to what our plan should be which was reasonable and which was the beginning of what became rather widespread overall planning for oceanography in the Navy program.
which of course has ballooned since up into great organizations like NOAA.
But in order to get funding, they saw that such a plan would have to be laid out and then approved by the then Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Jim Wakelin, and others in order to get going.
It was very rough.
but it was a beginning and was a milestone in the organization and planning for research and development in the Navy in oceanography.

But I return to the informal coordinating committee on oceanography established by Lill as the first establishment of lines of communication between the different government agencies and the interplay of their work.

such as on shipbuilding and ship construction, which included the Maritime Commission, the beginnings of the attempts to have a list of oceanographic instrumentation and some guidelines and standards for them, and multiple problems and great activities aiming for the same area.
The 1950s were interesting and exciting years.
There were enough old-timers left around in places of importance in the Bureau of Ships to be able to say, yes, we can do this.
There were enough people with technical know-how and confidence based on the building of over a thousand ships and all of its parts to be able to say, yes, this can be done.
And with enough imagination, and perhaps also due to the boredom of peacetime operations,
A great deal of technical and managerial assistance was given on any project that captured their imagination.

As one example, which came later, after Bob Dietz had given such a favorable report on Picard's Bathyscaphe, the Trieste, and after O&R had bought it, and after O&R had made the deep dive in the Marianas Trench with Don Walsh
and Pickard with Andy Rechnitzer and Shoemaker with the other members of the team.
The bathyscaphe was turned over, Trieste was turned over to the Bureau of Ships for future funding.
It was too much, too big an item out of ONR's then just growing budget to be handled.
And it was with surprise and delight that a captain
off the cuff, as it were, said we will have $800,000 out of King's program for the Trieste.
As simple as that.
Furthermore, the contracting activities of the Bureau of Ships were used to dealing in millions of dollars and making decisions based on what they considered adequate information.
And although in general principles

the contractor with the lowest bid was given most consideration, there were certain areas in which the Bureau very wisely permitted sole source procurement, that is, procurement from a designated agent who was qualified to give the answers that were needed.
On that basis, the Woods Holbrook was supported directly for many years from Bureau ships,

plus O&R contracts also, but from the Bureau of Ships contract at least, we could cite all the way back the history of the development of the bathymograph as the reason for sole source procurement, in other words, buying the type of research from them which we specified in their program as approved and funded, to be funded for the year.
The same was true of Lamont,
And Ewing's work and the beautiful maps of Bruce Hazen were always prime number one exhibits, long before the Geographic brought them out, to show what we were learning about the bottom of the ocean.
The same was true of Scripps, until Owen Awe took over the majority of that contract.
My particular effort, which had some success, was the development of R&D programs in oceanography in the Navy Control Laboratories.
It was always an interesting and fascinating problem to find a research project which fitted
a particular man's capability in a laboratory, as well as a laboratory mission, and also in the development of oceanographic research.
Sometimes it was easy.
Out at the Navy Electronics Laboratory was a group interested in Arctic research with submarines under Dr. Waldo K. Lyon.

And although we funded him many years for studies of sea ice and all that sort of thing too, we were always supported and delightfully supported by certain areas in the Chief of Naval Operations who knew, which we did not always know, that Dr. Lyon and his group were really laying the foundation for what later became the famous Nautilus cruise and the cruise of the under-ice submarines.

But throughout all the years the major justification was the improvement of sonar, the lineal descendant of the original studies of afternoon effect and the Bathley thermograph, studies of internal waves, studies of bottom topography, the original installations of Ewing's three original SOFAR stations for sound fixing and navigation,
at Point Arenas, I believe Point Sur, and Kaneohe, an unclassified system that operated for a while until the cables went out but proved the fact that it could be done.
This little project upon which so much later work in the Navy hung should not be forgotten because with it, after the system was assessed,

A small four-pound bomb of TNT hydrostatically fused to go off at the sound channel about 200 meters down or more could be heard at the three stations and a fix made of where it had occurred in the best portions of an ellipse six miles by a mile and a half wide, which was a pretty good location
of any downed aircraft of those days.
Had this system been maintained, the Navy could have saved far more than its original cost as it searched for airplanes lost in the Pacific.
Even after the Port Arenas station went out, the link between Point Sour and Kaneohe was used for basic research in underwater sound for many years.
At the risk of repetition, I have now found a part of an old speech which I want to read into the record as it points up some of the persons involved.
These persons come under the names of Master Planners.
Jim Wakelin and the Assistant Secretary of the Navy Establishment have already mentioned it.
And now repeating a little bit.

Master planners, the first one military man, for all this began in 1941 and 42, the late Rosson Bennett II, Railroad Mark, USN, one of MTS's first directors, and the Coal Pitchers Committee, the National Academy of Sciences, who said, go all out for oceanography if you want to improve underwater sound, so not performance.
And through Bennett and his group would channel the funding and direction and
and direction helped and given to the National Defense Research Committee.
The fundings were in millions of dollars.
From Woods Hole down to Washington came Columbus Islin, who has been honored recently in many speeches, and Morris Ewing.
And from NIRL there was help, and from Scripps came H. Hughes-Feldrup and Walter Monk in the way of predictions.
And right into the middle bench group came Roger Avell,
You must see him with Marston Sargent as his first assistant, and Mary Sears, Dr. Mary Sears, now Woods Hole, who was then a wave out at the hydrographic office.
And among the planners must be mentioned those starlets who emerged in the war or planning in the Navy laboratories.
Some have left us, like it.

Houghton and Guy Harris at New London, and at San Diego, Dr. Christensen and Don Wilson, and at Buschips, the original marine physical laboratory at Point Loma, where we had a series of powerful directors, Carl Eckert, Sir Charles Wright, Al Folk, and now later Fred Spies.
Very few people know how much oceanography owes Roger Revelle.
Suffice it to say that he implemented the contracts and was a prime mover in establishing ONR and our international posture.
For 15 years, under one of his operational requirements, placed on the Bureau of Ships and ONR, one of the essential papers in the history of oceanography in the Navy.
laid on equally on BUSH ships and ONR the job of continuing long-time research.
In fact, in nine short sentences, he justified the Navy in doing any kind of work needed for marine research through the war and in the post-war years and later.
An essential group in oceanography at this time in the early 50s was the Deepwater Propagation Committee back at Hersey as chairman.
It had no schedule.
It was a smoke filled room where review and decisions were made and the work carried out under the ONR and BUSHIP's contracts.
At a typical meeting, say at Dobbs Ferry, the host would be Bob Frosch for Hudson Laboratories
Al Berman, for Woods Hole, Al Vine, for Lamont, Joe Wazell, for Underwater Sound Lab, Guy Harris, for NEL, Gilbert Curl.
Down to bishops came Alan Vine from Woods Hole also, for many terms of duty.
In the 1950s, he joined Dick Williams, Vernon Potter, and Ned Shear, all under a crusty, fair-minded driver and assistant to Boston Bennett named George Cummings.
Over at ONR was Gordon Lill and Art Maxwell, Don Martineau, Phenon Jennings.
Lill started the original Coordinating Committee for Oceanography, which became the Interagency Committee on Oceanography with Bob Abel, and which had a crucial part in the Stratton Report.
Dick Vetter left Lill's group at ONR to become secretary to Harrison Brown's National Committee for Oceanography.
and kept it human with his reports called NASCO Notes and Doodles.
Please continue on side five.
Please continue.
